articles.headline: Madoff Aide Reveals Details of Ponzi Scheme
articles.snippet: Frank DiPascali, a longtime employee of Bernard L. Madoff, pleaded guilty to his role in the Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Frank DiPascali, a longtime employee of Bernard L. Madoff, pleaded guilty to his role in the Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frank DiPascali was a “kid from Queens” fresh out of high school when he landed a job in 1975 with a rising star on Wall Street named Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: Debate in Germany: Research or Manufacturing?
articles.snippet: As more investment goes to research, Germans are confronting the idea that manufacturing may not be their economy’s indispensable foundation.
articles.abstract: As more investment goes to research, Germans are confronting the idea that manufacturing may not be their economy’s indispensable foundation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany  In recent months, two big computer chip makers slipped through Dresden’s fingers, challenging the notion that an area that likes to think of itself as “Silicon Saxony” can continue to churn out high-technology devices by the millions. But not every inhabitant of this picturesque city considers that a bad thing.

articles.headline: E-Mail Reveals Rove’s Key Role in ’06 Dismissals
articles.snippet: Documents showed Karl Rove and others played a more active role in the 2006 firings of federal prosecutors.
articles.abstract: Documents showed Karl Rove and others played a more active role in the 2006 firings of federal prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Thousands of pages of internal e-mail and once-secret Congressional testimony showed Tuesday that Karl Rove and other senior aides in the Bush White House played an earlier and more active role than was previously known in the 2006 firings of a number of United States attorneys.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: G.M. Hopes New Lineup Brings Back Excitement
articles.snippet: The automaker says it wants to attract buyers who value economy and technology over size and horsepower.
articles.abstract: The automaker says it wants to attract buyers who value economy and technology over size and horsepower.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich.  General Motors is focusing on smaller cars and more fuel-efficient vehicles to lure back consumers who had given up on the struggling auto giant.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Shiites Show Restraint After Attacks
articles.snippet: The Shiites, habituated to suffering by centuries as the region’s underclass, have convinced their followers they win by not responding with violence.
articles.abstract: The Shiites, habituated to suffering by centuries as the region’s underclass, have convinced their followers they win by not responding with violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Shiite clerics and politicians have been successfully urging their followers not to retaliate against a fierce campaign of sectarian bombings, in which Shiites have accounted for most of the 566 Iraqis killed since American troops pulled out of Iraq’s cities on June 30.

articles.headline: Corporations Take a Low-Key Approach to Event Sponsorship
articles.snippet: Worried about seeming ostentatious, major businesses that entertain clients do so very quietly.
articles.abstract: Worried about seeming ostentatious, major businesses that entertain clients do so very quietly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even in these tough times, major corporations are spending to entertain valued clients at golf tournaments and exclusive receptions.

articles.headline: A Soldier’s Eye in the Sky
articles.snippet: U.S. Army officials say smaller technologies and robotic tools could make a difference in some of the most dangerous missions.
articles.abstract: U.S. Army officials say smaller technologies and robotic tools could make a difference in some of the most dangerous missions.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT BLISS, Tex.  The soldiers crouched beneath the blazing desert sun, waiting to burst into the villages in conditions similar to those they have encountered in Iraq and Afghanistan.

articles.headline: 2 U.S. Architects of Harsh Tactics in 9/11’s Wake
articles.snippet: In 2002, two psychologists found a business opportunity selling interrogation and training services to the C.I.A.
articles.abstract: In 2002, two psychologists found a business opportunity selling interrogation and training services to the C.I.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Jim Mitchell and Bruce Jessen were military retirees and psychologists, on the lookout for business opportunities. They found an excellent customer in the Central Intelligence Agency, where in 2002 they became the architects of the most important interrogation program in the history of American counterterrorism.

articles.headline: W.T.O. Rules Against China’s Limits on Imports
articles.snippet: The decision was seen as a victory for the United States at a time when China is being perceived as increasingly nationalistic in its trade policies.
articles.abstract: The decision was seen as a victory for the United States at a time when China is being perceived as increasingly nationalistic in its trade policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  The World Trade Organization gave the United States a victory on Wednesday in its trade battle with China, ruling that Beijing had violated international rules by limiting imports of books, songs and movies.
